title: Charles Michael, Duke of Mecklenburg
text:
Charles Michael, Duke of Mecklenburg (; ; – 6 December 1934) was an officer in the <a href="Imperial%20Russian%20Army">Imperial Russian Army</a>, <a href="heir%20presumptive">heir presumptive</a> to the throne of <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Mecklenburg-Strelitz">Mecklenburg-Strelitz</a> and from 1918 head of the <a href="House%20of%20Mecklenburg">Grand Ducal House</a>.
Life in Russia.
He was born in <a href="Oranienbaum%2C%20Russia">Oranienbaum, Russia</a>, a grandson of <a href="Georg%2C%20Grand%20Duke%20of%20Mecklenburg-Strelitz">Grand Duke Georg of Mecklenburg-Strelitz</a> via his second son Duke Georg August of Mecklenburg (1824–1876) and his wife <a href="Grand%20Duchess%20Catherine%20Mikhailovna%20of%20Russia">Grand Duchess Catherine Mikhailovna of Russia</a>, a granddaughter of Emperor <a href="Paul%20I%20of%20Russia">Paul I of Russia</a>. Charles Michael studied at the <a href="University%20of%20Strasbourg">University of Strasbourg</a> and gained a <a href="PhD">PhD</a>. As he was born into the Russian branch of the Grand Ducal house of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, Charles Michael and his older brother Duke George Alexander, both served in the Russian Imperial Army with Charles Michael achieving the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20General">Lieutenant General</a>. When his brother died in 1909 Charles Michael was appointed the guardian of his children Katharina, Marie, Natalia and <a href="Duke%20Georg%20of%20Mecklenburg">Georg</a> by Adolf Friedrich V. From 1908 to 1910, he served as the head of artillery in the <a href="1st%20Army%20Corps%20%28Russian%20Empire%29">1st Army Corps</a> of the Russian Imperial Army.
On 24 June 1914 two weeks after the death of his cousin <a href="Adolf%20Friedrich%20V%2C%20Grand%20Duke%20of%20Mecklenburg-Strelitz">Grand Duke Adolf Friedrich V</a>, Charles Michael wrote to the new Grand Duke <a href="Adolf%20Friedrich%20VI%2C%20Grand%20Duke%20of%20Mecklenburg-Strelitz">Adolf Friedrich VI</a> informing him that he wished to renounce his rights to the throne of <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Mecklenburg-Strelitz">Mecklenburg-Strelitz</a>. On 7 August shortly after the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> he became a <a href="naturalised">naturalised</a> Russian citizen.
In March, 1917 Charles Michael was arrested and made to appear before the Russian parliament the <a href="Duma">Duma</a>. He later fled to the <a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> region.
Heir to Strelitz.
The Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, <a href="Frederick%20Francis%20IV%2C%20Grand%20Duke%20of%20Mecklenburg-Schwerin">Friedrich Franz IV</a> wrote to Charles Michael informing him that his cousin Adolf Friedrich VI of Mecklenburg-Strelitz had died on 23 February 1918 and that as he was first in the line of succession he was being called to the throne. A petition to accept the throne was also sent to Charles Michael by the citizens of Mecklenburg-Strelitz as they wanted to maintain their independence and not be united with <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Mecklenburg-Schwerin">Mecklenburg-Schwerin</a>. However Charles Michael never received it so he wrote a private letter confirming his desire to renounce his rights to reign in Mecklenburg-Strelitz although the letter did not reach Friedrich Franz IV, who was acting as regent for Mecklenburg-Strelitz, until January 1919 after the fall of the German monarchies. As a result, the succession issue could not be resolved in time and the two Mecklenburg grand duchies became separate <a href="Free%20State%20of%20Mecklenburg-Schwerin">free state</a>s in the <a href="Weimar%20Republic">Weimar Republic</a>.
Charles Michael eventually left Russia with his family arriving first in <a href="France">France</a> before going into exile in <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>. While there he served as Chairman of the Mutual Charitable Society for Russian Officers in Denmark. In 1921 he was paid five million <a href="German%20Papiermark">mark</a>s by the Mecklenburg government in return for renouncing his claim to the Strelitz throne. In April, 1930 he returned to Germany and took up residence at his estate, <a href="Remplin">Remplin</a> castle.
Charles Michael adopted his nephew <a href="Duke%20Georg%20of%20Mecklenburg">Georg, Count of Carlow</a> who was the <a href="morganatic">morganatic</a> son of his older brother <a href="Duke%20Georg%20Alexander%20of%20Mecklenburg-Strelitz">Duke George Alexander of Mecklenburg</a> (1859–1909) on 11 September 1928 and confirmed in the courts of <a href="Malchin">Malchin</a> on 5 October 1928. Charles Michael died unmarried in <a href="Remplin">Remplin</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a> and was succeeded as head of the Grand Ducal house by his nephew and adopted son the former Count of Carlow, <a href="Duke%20Georg%20of%20Mecklenburg">Duke Georg of Mecklenburg</a>.
